prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3mm monitoring of NGC7469
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a project to monitor daily the radio core on NGC7469 in band 3 at 95 GHz. This monitor will be simultaneous with a Swift X-ray campaign in the period Dec 8 - Dec 21 2015. This systematic and simultaneous mm and X-ray monitoring would explore the conjecture that accretion disk corona is responsible to account for the radio emission in Radio Quiet Active Galactic Nuclei.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note:
We plan to monitor the target at 95 GHz simultaneously with a X-ray monitoring program. An approved Swift intensive campaign of NGC7469 has been accpted with an increasing cadence which will peak in mid November 2015 when Swift will observe NGC7469 every day from November 15th - December 31st. Therefore we propose to observe NGC7469 daily between December 8th - December 21st with ALMA in band 3. We are aware that the current ALMA schedule is two weeks of science observations followed by one week of EoC (engeneering). Therefore, based on that we decide to observe for 14 days starting on the first day of a science observations two-week block. The ALMA support told us that these specific blocks will start on December 8th.
Furthermore, we set a margin on the daily visit of 0.5 day to slightly relax the intensive cadence and not to overlap. Despite this margin, we officially request 14 flux measurements. However, in light of the restrictive weather conditions for mm observations, and the scheduling constraints of ALMA, we are aware of the possibility that not all 14 observations will be performed, but we request at least 12 visits.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose to observe single continuum emission from NGC7469 radio core. This automatically defines a maximum bandwidth (7.5 GHz) and low spectral resolution correlator setup.

Low resolution radio maps of NGC7469 show an extension of ~10arcsec. This is consistent with our requested largest angular scale. The resolution we wish to achieve is 1 arcsec in order to resolve a region of ~300 pc of the radio core. This high angular resolution allows us to separate the radio core component, which is responsible to vary, and the extended jet emission, which is supposed to be constant in flux. Furthermore, the high resolution also allows us to probe smaller region (closer to the black hole) which is expected to show larger 95-GHz variability amplitude, approaching to the X-ray variability that is on the time scale of a day.

In a pilot monitoring of NGC7469 with the CARMA telescope (Baldi et al 2015, in prep) we have detected its 95 GHz continuum which varies between 2 and 4 mJy with a resolution of 2.2 arcsec. Now we assume that we want to detect the lowest peak flux density of 2 mJy in band 3. However, since ALMA has a better angular resolution we can resolve smaller radio core component which is associated with a minor flux density than CARMA data. Therefore we request to achieve a RMS of at least 0.1 mJY to increase the detection limit. This high sensitivity would also allow us to increase the detection of the intrinsic 95GHz variability up to 5% (20sigma) in case of a factor 2 variability. Although we are interested in band-3 baseband-2 which we set at 95 GHz, the expected RMS in this band is 1.38 mJy that is still feasible enough to achieve our goal.

We set the sky frequency at 100 GHz in mm-band in order to center the baseband-2 of the B3 band on 95 GHz (3 mm). This frequency falls in a largely unexplored band between 50 and 300 GHz, between the synchrotron emission from the core/jets and the steep rise of the spectrum due to the low frequency tail of the thermal dust emission. The mm-band radio observations bring several advantages. First, the emitting source becomes more transparent because the synchrotron self absorption is reduced. Secondly, we can probe smaller region of emission, about 20 times smaller than a 5-Ghz emitting core. Furthermore, the variability at the mm-band is expected to be about 20 times faster than at the cm-band. Furthermore, since we already have previous 95-GHz detection of the target from the CARMA telescope (Behar et al submitted, Baldi et al in prep), an ALMA 95-GHz detection gives us the opportunity to a straightforward comparison with previous data.

We ask to monitor the 95-GHz continuum flux of NGC7469 with daily visits between December 8th to December 21th, in order to obtain a 14-day light curve. This time constraint is planned to match the accepted Swift monitoring in X-ray band of this source in the same period with a daily cadence. We relax the intensive campaign setting a 0.5 day margin on the observations. However, we officially request 14 visits on the source.
We are aware that the current ALMA schedule is two weeks of science observations followed by one week of EoC (engineering). Therefore, based on that we decide to observe for 14 days starting on the first day of a science observations two-week block. The ALMA support told us that these specific blocks will start on December 8th for the following 14 days until December 21st. We select this two weeks because they will complement the IRAM observations from November 15th to November 30th.
A daily schedule and regular visits would help the correlation with the X-ray light curve. Based on our experience, we can build a light curve with 14 data points to measure significant source variability and its fundamental parameters such as variance, Rmax, and Fvar (Edelson et al 2002), as well as to obtain an exploratory cross correlation with the Swift X-ray light curve. In light of the restrictive weather conditions for mm observations, and the scheduling constraints of ALMA, we are aware of the possibility that not all 14 observations will be performed, but we request at least 12 visits. To that end, it is important to note that the mere detection of variability at 95 GHz would be an important discovery; identification of a typical variability time scale would be most significant; and the bonus of 95 GHz / X-ray correlated variability would represent a major breakthrough in the understanding of accretion-disk physics.The total integrated time which includes calibration, multiple pointings, and the 14 visits is 5.06 hours.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: What is the origin of radio emission from radio-quiet (RQ) active galactic nuclei (AGN)? Is it just a scaled down version of the jet emission seen in radio-loud AGN? Or does it originate in the accretion disk corona, as seen in coronaly active stars? We propose to use the unique opportunity of an intensive, fully scheduled, multi-wavelength monitoring campaign of NGC7469 (including Swift, XMM-Newton, NuSTAR, HST, and IRAM) and use ALMA to explore the relation of the mm emission with the coronal X-ray emission at high precision. This exploratory study will allow us to establish if the mm emission can be used as a new and powerful method to explore the structure and dynamics of the innermost part of the accretion disk in AGN.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: In 2015, an intensive (fully scheduled) multi-wavelength monitoring campaign of NGC7469 will be carried out, utilizing three X-ray observatories (Swift, XMM-Newton, and NuSTAR), HST and IRAM to simultaneously observe NGC7469. From hundreds of hours worth of X-ray observing time, a precise characterization of the X-ray source and its variability on various timescales will be obtained. Most important for this proposal is the Swift monitoring, which will start in Oct. 2015 with an increasing cadence that will peak in mid Nov. 2015 when Swift will observe NGC7469 every day from Nov. 15 - Dec. 31. The approved Swift X-ray campaign of NGC7469, along with ALMA sensitivity provides a unique opportunity to perform the proposed X-ray/mm monitoring, which will be possible only during this ALMA cycle 3, and for which the other telescopes are not sufficiently sensitive.
